para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-1-103 governs offers of proof. An offer of proof informs the judge of the nature of the material sought to be introduced so that he may rule on its admissibility. Also, it provides a means by which counsel, after the trial court sustains an objection to a question or a line of testimony, can preserve the matter for appellate review by placing the rejected testimony or a summary of it into the record.[1] However, a formal offer of proof is not necessary to preserve an objection for trail, and an appellant is entitled to ordinary appellate review of a ruling excluding evidence where the substance of the evidence is apparent to the court from its context.[2]

The Georgia Court of Appeals may grant a new trial when “any material evidence may be illegally admitted to or illegally withheld from the jury over the objection of the movant.”[3] The appellate court must know what evidence the trial court excluded before it can review the exclusion. If the alleged error is based on the court's refusal to permit a witness to answer a question, then the judge and the appellate court must be informed as to what the answer would have been.[4] Likewise, an appellant must include and explain, on the record, both the content of his offer of proof and how that content would have helped the trier of fact in understanding the area of inquiry.[5]

An appellant's claim that the trial court erred in refusing to admit a letter into evidence failed because the appellant had not included the letter in the record or read its contents into the transcript during trial and the Court of Appeals had nothing to review.[6]
Dickens v. State, 280 Ga. 320, 323 n.3, 627 S.E.2d 587 (2006); Wallace v. State, 294 Ga. App. 159, 669 S.E.2d 400 (2008).

Counsel's statement in place regarding the rejected testimony promotes judicial economy by allowing an abbreviated version of excluded testimony from a willing-to-testify witness to be placed on the record for appellate review rather than utilizing court resources involved in calling and questioning that witness outside the jury's presence regarding the excluded testimony. Dickens v. State, 280 Ga. 320, 627 S.E.2d 587 (2006); Wallace v. State, 294 Ga. App. 159, 669 S.E.2d 400 (2008).
Williams v. State, 332 Ga. App. 546, 774 S.E.2d 126 (2015).
Hines v. Donaldson, 193 Ga. 783, 20 S.E.2d 134 (1942); Campbell v. State, 149 Ga. App. 299, 254 S.E.2d 389 (1979).

Even assuming the exclusion of testimony from the witness for the stated reason was error, without any offer of proof showing how the expected testimony would have been material or beneficial, there was no basis to seek reversal on appeal. BBC Land and Development, Inc. v. Bank of North Georgia, 294 Ga. App. 759, 670 S.E.2d 210 (2008).
O'Brien v. Lewis, 2019 WL 2521143 (Ga. Ct. App. 2019).
Schulz v. Sherwinter, 227 Ga. App. 380, 489 S.E.2d 348 (1997).
